The Anabasis of Alexander (, "Alexándrou Anábasis"; ) was composed by Arrian of Nicomedia in the second century AD, most probably during the reign of Hadrian. The "Anabasis" (which survives complete in seven books) is a history of the campaigns of Alexander the Great, specifically his conquest of the Persian Empire between 336 and 323 BC. Both the unusual title "Anabasis" (literally "a journey up-country from the sea") and the work's seven-book structure reflect Arrian's emulation (in structure, style, and content) of the Greek historian Xenophon, whose own "Anabasis" in seven books concerned the earlier campaign "up-country" of Cyrus the Younger in 401 BC.

Anabasis (; ; an "expedition up from") is the most famous book of the Ancient Greek professional soldier and writer Xenophon. The seven-tome book of the "Anabasis" was composed around the year 370 BC, and, in translation, "Anabasis" is rendered as The March of the Ten Thousand and as The March Up Country.
